titleStmt.title: conversation about positions at universities in different countries
titleStmt.funder: VOICE is funded by FWF, the Austrian Science Fund (Project No. L448)

publicationStmt.publisher: Barbara Seidlhofer, Stefan Majewski, Ruth Osimk-Teasdale, Marie-Luise Pitzl, Michael Radeka
publicationStmt.distributor: VOICE Project, University of Vienna, Austria

availability.p: The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (VOICE) was created by Barbara Seidlhofer (project director) and Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Marie-Luise Pitzl (project researchers). Minor revisions were gathered by Ruth Osimk-Teasdale and Michael Radeka and corrections were made by Ruth Osimk-Teasdale. VOICE 2.0 XML is available for download at the VOICE Project's website http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/ under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-NC-SA 3.0) License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/). The original audio files are held at the Department of English, University of Vienna. 23 selected audio files are available as audio streams in the VOICE Online interface at the VOICE Project's website http://www.univie.ac.at/voice.
The recommended citation for VOICE 2.0 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2013. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (version 2.0 XML). Director: Barbara Seidlhofer; Researchers: Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Ruth Osimk-Teasdale, Marie-Luise Pitzl, Michael Radeka.

availability.p: The short citation for VOICE 2.0 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2013. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (version 2.0 XML).

availability.p: For further information about availability and copyright permissions, please see the README file included in the download package. For further enquiries please contact the VOICE Project at voice@univie.ac.at.

notesStmt.note: This conversation takes place at a reception at an international conference on distributed computing. S5, S6 and S7 are approached by S1. After S1 has asked for permission to record the conversation, S5, S6 and S7 continue their conversation. They talk about differences between national university systems as regards PhD positions and professorial positions. After a couple of minutes, S5 turns to S1 and asks her how she knew about the conference. S1 is now actively involved in the conversation with S5, S6 and S7. The topic shifts towards English as an international language, the language of immigrants in Germany and the (un)importance people's accents.

equipment.p: Portable minidisc recorder with electret condenser stereo microphone

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark a stretch of speech commonly preceded and followed by a pause or by a change of speaker. A u is, however, not required to be bounded by a pause or a change of speaker, nor does it represent a turn in a conversation analytic sense. At a minimum, a u is some phonetic production or noise made by a given speaker or a group of speakers.
Used to mark a pause either between or within utterances. Used without dur attribute to indicate a brief pause up to half a second.

Used to mark lengthening of sounds and intonation (fall, rise). The following type attributes are used to mark:
lengthening
lengthened sounds intonation
a significant change in intonation, marked with the following function attribute for:
fall
falling intonation rise
rising intonation
Intonation may or may not coincide with syntactic boundaries.
Used to mark speech which is stressed or emphasized in a way that goes beyond regular nuclear stress.

Used to mark points where a short portion of speech has not been recorded or has been left untranscribed, whether for editorial reasons, as part of the sampling practice, or because the material is inaudible or comprises sensitive content. The following reason attributes are used to mark:
not_recorded
Not recorded speech not_transcribed
Not transcribed speech
Further information on the reason for a gap is provided within the voice:desc attribute.

Used to mark the point at which some paralinguistic feature changes. The following attribute values are used to mark:
voice
voice quality
imitating
laugh
neutral
phone
reading
reading_aloud
sigh
singing
whisp
yawning
tempo
speed of utterance
a
accelerando l
lento neutral
neutral
loud
loudness
f
neutral
p

Used to mark laughter and other speaker noises and non-verbal feedback.
speaker_noise
coughing
nods
shakes head
smacks lips
sniffs
swallows
whistles
wordlike
laughing

Used with different type attributes to mark:
typeoverlap
overlaps typeonomatopoeia
onomatopoeic sounds typeipa
transcriptions in the international phonetic alphabet

Used to mark other-continuation, i.e. whenever a speaker continues another speaker's u without a pause. Other-continuation is to be interpreted temporally and does not relate to form or content of the speakers' utterances.
Used to mark speech which cannot be transcribed with certainty, because it is difficult to hear or understand for the transcriber.
Used with the type attribute set to spelt to mark words or word fragments which are spelt out, i.e. words whose constituents are pronounced as individual letters.

Used to mark text supplied by the transcriber because the original is unintelligible or needed to be anonymized. The reason attribute is used to mark:
unintelligible
unintelligible speech anonymization
anonymized speech

Used to mark a word or phrase as belonging to some language other than English. The following values for the type attribute are used to mark:
L1
the speaker's first language LN
a language other than the speaker's first language LQ
a language where it cannot be ascertained whether it is the speaker's first or other language.
Whenever possible, the voice:translation attribute provides a rough translation of the non-English speech into English.
Used to mark contextual information relevant to the understanding of the interaction or the interaction as such. The voice:desc attribute provides a short prose description of the contextual event.

namespace.name: http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark a pronunciation variation or coinage as described in the VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1].the VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1]. An existing word corresponding to the PVC may be provided within a commentcomment attribute within the voice:pvcvoice:pvc element. Additional phonetic transcription may be provided within a voice:ipavoice:ipa attribute within the voice:pvcvoice:pvc element.
Used to mark the beginning of a new audio track used in transcription (usually three minutes in length) and thus refers to the audio recording of the transcribed speech event.
Used to mark speech directed towards a particular speaker. The whowho attribute indicates the addressed speaker.

div.u: hello excuse me i'm from vienna university from the english department and er we are doing a project on intercultural communication and me and my colleague are here to collect data so i was wondering if i could record your conversation for a project it's totally anonymous

and er may i ask you where you are from
may i ask you where you are from

then you can apply for er associate professorships or for full professorships xx
typically you you apply for associate professorships and only the associate professorships they are er and the full professorships hh they're for a lifetime positions
so all the other are only for some how how do you call that in english
so er are you have to opp- the xxx xx

for a x p h d thesis the deadline is five years with the possibility of erm getting one additional year

france they have even a shorter limit
i don't know three years i think

ah well well i guess er more or less well we take a- o- on average we take five years to get p h d
so i i guess three years er is not enough is not enough
erm well yo- you may take more time for the for your p h d thesis but er in that case
you can't be erm an assistant at the university the university pays you only
for five or six years and if you don't have your p h d th- degree finished or your p h d thesis finished erm you have to find another job
and have you do you have to finish the p h d thesis in your erm space time
mhm i see and yeah er d- does your country have the same promotion system meaning assistant professor and associate professor and full professor
for now i think for one or two years there is a junior professor
i don't know exactly the details about it
aha yeah w- we have er three ranks er assistant professor and associate and full professor
and usually we have six y- years for to be assistant professor meaning after six years we have to either promote it or go off for somewhere
so we have usually six y- years of window time window
and then we have to show er we have to demonstrate the research capab- research and teaching capability er research meaning er our papers or usually papers
and teaching or teaching evaluation from students
and then and then and then we are promoted to associate x
the main difference is that we can never be a professor at the same university they have er
and also as er as i said you can no- you have to change again er to become a full professor
you must bu- you must always change the university
you can never stay in the same place
aha i see i see hh and how many er faculty members do you have in your department how many professors
er we have only nine nine in the department of computer science so
mhm because we don't count erm
i see yeah so my department has er sixteen er faculty members
and two lecturers er but it's not the same thing as w- as w- with your department because x you don't have assistant professors
that that's interesting okay an- an- and how did you know we are gathering here at this time
well erm we have the information from my colleagues because we are continually researching
and trying to find er meetings international meetings in vienna
where people from different cultures and different first languages meet
and er so we came across your meeting and we contacted the organizer and
he said okay you can come
have you registered with the conference

well we are looking for linguistic factors it depends on on actually if er if somebody wants to do a project on or wants to write a paper on on er on english as an international language then

it's about erm which language people use and how they use it and the way they communicate with each other
